summary.long: Song Of Solomon is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The song of songs, which is Solomon’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth: for thy love is better than wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of the savour of thy good ointments thy name is as ointment poured forth, therefore do the virgins love thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Draw me, we will run after thee: the king hath brought me into his chambers: we will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more than wine: the upright love thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am black, but comely, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, as the tents of Kedar, as the curtains of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look not upon me, because I am black, because the sun hath looked upon me: my mother’s children were angry with me; they made me the keeper of the vineyards; but mine own vineyard have I not kept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth, where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon: for why should I be as one that turneth aside by the flocks of thy companions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If thou know not, O thou fairest among women, go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock, and feed thy kids beside the shepherds’ tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have compared thee, O my love, to a company of horses in Pharaoh’s chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy cheeks are comely with rows of jewels, thy neck with chains of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the king sitteth at his table, my spikenard sendeth forth the smell thereof.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A bundle of myrrh is my wellbeloved unto me; he shall lie all night betwixt my breasts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My beloved is unto me as a cluster of camphire in the vineyards of En-gedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves’ eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant: also our bed is green.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The beams of our house are cedar, and our rafters of fir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the rose of Sharon, and the lily of the valleys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the lily among thorns, so is my love among the daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the sons. I sat down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit was sweet to my taste.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me was love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples: for I am sick of love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His left hand is under my head, and his right hand doth embrace me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, till he please.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The voice of my beloved! behold, he cometh leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My beloved is like a roe or a young hart: behold, he standeth behind our wall, he looketh forth at the windows, shewing himself through the lattice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My beloved spake, and said unto me, Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing of birds is come, and the voice of the turtle is heard in our land;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fig tree putteth forth her green figs, and the vines with the tender grape give a good smell. Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs, let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice; for sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vines: for our vines have tender grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My beloved is mine, and I am his: he feedeth among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Until the day break, and the shadows flee away, turn, my beloved, and be thou like a roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth: I sought him, but I found him not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will rise now, and go about the city in the streets, and in the broad ways I will seek him whom my soul loveth: I sought him, but I found him not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The watchmen that go about the city found me: to whom I said, Saw ye him whom my soul loveth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was but a little that I passed from them, but I found him whom my soul loveth: I held him, and would not let him go, until I had brought him into my mother’s house, and into the chamber of her that conceived me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, till he please.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is this that cometh out of the wilderness like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, with all powders of the merchant?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold his bed, which is Solomon’s; threescore valiant men are about it, of the valiant of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They all hold swords, being expert in war: every man hath his sword upon his thigh because of fear in the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon made himself a chariot of the wood of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the pillars thereof of silver, the bottom thereof of gold, the covering of it of purple, the midst thereof being paved with love, for the daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion, and behold king Solomon with the crown wherewith his mother crowned him in the day of his espousals, and in the day of the gladness of his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves’ eyes within thy locks: thy hair is as a flock of goats, that appear from mount Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep that are even shorn, which came up from the washing; whereof every one bear twins, and none is barren among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy lips are like a thread of scarlet, and thy speech is comely: thy temples are like a piece of a pomegranate within thy locks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy neck is like the tower of David builded for an armoury, whereon there hang a thousand bucklers, all shields of mighty men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy two breasts are like two young roes that are twins, which feed among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Until the day break, and the shadows flee away, I will get me to the mountain of myrrh, and to the hill of frankincense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thou art all fair, my love; there is no spot in thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come with me from Lebanon, my spouse, with me from Lebanon: look from the top of Amana, from the top of Shenir and Hermon, from the lions’ dens, from the mountains of the leopards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thou hast ravished my heart, my sister, my spouse; thou hast ravished my heart with one of thine eyes, with one chain of thy neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How fair is thy love, my sister, my spouse! how much better is thy love than wine! and the smell of thine ointments than all spices!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy lips, O my spouse, drop as the honeycomb: honey and milk are under thy tongue; and the smell of thy garments is like the smell of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A garden inclosed is my sister, my spouse; a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy plants are an orchard of pomegranates, with pleasant fruits; camphire, with spikenard,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Spikenard and saffron; calamus and cinnamon, with all trees of frankincense; myrrh and aloes, with all the chief spices:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A fountain of gardens, a well of living waters, and streams from Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Awake, O north wind; and come, thou south; blow upon my garden, that the spices thereof may flow out. Let my beloved come into his garden, and eat his pleasant fruits.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am come into my garden, my sister, my spouse: I have gathered my myrrh with my spice; I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey; I have drunk my wine with my milk: eat, O friends; drink, yea, drink abundantly, O beloved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I sleep, but my heart waketh: it is the voice of my beloved that knocketh, saying, Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled: for my head is filled with dew, and my locks with the drops of the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have put off my coat; how shall I put it on? I have washed my feet; how shall I defile them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My beloved put in his hand by the hole of the door, and my bowels were moved for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I rose up to open to my beloved; and my hands dropped with myrrh, and my fingers with sweet smelling myrrh, upon the handles of the lock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I opened to my beloved; but my beloved had withdrawn himself, and was gone: my soul failed when he spake: I sought him, but I could not find him; I called him, but he gave me no answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The watchmen that went about the city found me, they smote me, they wounded me; the keepers of the walls took away my veil from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if ye find my beloved, that ye tell him, that I am sick of love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What is thy beloved more than another beloved, O thou fairest among women? what is thy beloved more than another beloved, that thou dost so charge us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My beloved is white and ruddy, the chiefest among ten thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His head is as the most fine gold, his locks are bushy, and black as a raven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His eyes are as the eyes of doves by the rivers of waters, washed with milk, and fitly set.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His cheeks are as a bed of spices, as sweet flowers: his lips like lilies, dropping sweet smelling myrrh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His hands are as gold rings set with the beryl: his belly is as bright ivory overlaid with sapphires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His legs are as pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold: his countenance is as Lebanon, excellent as the cedars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His mouth is most sweet: yea, he is altogether lovely. This is my beloved, and this is my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whither is thy beloved gone, O thou fairest among women? whither is thy beloved turned aside? that we may seek him with thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My beloved is gone down into his garden, to the beds of spices, to feed in the gardens, and to gather lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine: he feedeth among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thou art beautiful, O my love, as Tirzah, comely as Jerusalem, terrible as an army with banners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Turn away thine eyes from me, for they have overcome me: thy hair is as a flock of goats that appear from Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy teeth are as a flock of sheep which go up from the washing, whereof every one beareth twins, and there is not one barren among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a piece of a pomegranate are thy temples within thy locks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There are threescore queens, and fourscore concubines, and virgins without number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My dove, my undefiled is but one; she is the only one of her mother, she is the choice one of her that bare her. The daughters saw her, and blessed her; yea, the queens and the concubines, and they praised her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is she that looketh forth as the morning, fair as the moon, clear as the sun, and terrible as an army with banners?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I went down into the garden of nuts to see the fruits of the valley, and to see whether the vine flourished, and the pomegranates budded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Or ever I was aware, my soul made me like the chariots of Amminadib.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Return, return, O Shulamite; return, return, that we may look upon thee. What will ye see in the Shulamite? As it were the company of two armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How beautiful are thy feet with shoes, O prince’s daughter! the joints of thy thighs are like jewels, the work of the hands of a cunning workman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy navel is like a round goblet, which wanteth not liquor: thy belly is like an heap of wheat set about with lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy two breasts are like two young roes that are twins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thy neck is as a tower of ivory; thine eyes like the fishpools in Heshbon, by the gate of Bath-rabbim: thy nose is as the tower of Lebanon which looketh toward Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thine head upon thee is like Carmel, and the hair of thine head like purple; the king is held in the galleries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How fair and how pleasant art thou, O love, for delights!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This thy stature is like to a palm tree, and thy breasts to clusters of grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said, I will go up to the palm tree, I will take hold of the boughs thereof: now also thy breasts shall be as clusters of the vine, and the smell of thy nose like apples;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the roof of thy mouth like the best wine for my beloved, that goeth down sweetly, causing the lips of those that are asleep to speak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am my beloved’s, and his desire is toward me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field; let us lodge in the villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let us get up early to the vineyards; let us see if the vine flourish, whether the tender grape appear, and the pomegranates bud forth: there will I give thee my loves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The mandrakes give a smell, and at our gates are all manner of pleasant fruits, new and old, which I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O that thou wert as my brother, that sucked the breasts of my mother! when I should find thee without, I would kiss thee; yea, I should not be despised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I would lead thee, and bring thee into my mother’s house, who would instruct me: I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine of the juice of my pomegranate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His left hand should be under my head, and his right hand should embrace me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, until he please.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is this that cometh up from the wilderness, leaning upon her beloved? I raised thee up under the apple tree: there thy mother brought thee forth: there she brought thee forth that bare thee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Set me as a seal upon thine heart, as a seal upon thine arm: for love is strong as death; jealousy is cruel as the grave: the coals thereof are coals of fire, which hath a most vehement flame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it: if a man would give all the substance of his house for love, it would utterly be contemned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have a little sister, and she hath no breasts: what shall we do for our sister in the day when she shall be spoken for?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If she be a wall, we will build upon her a palace of silver: and if she be a door, we will inclose her with boards of cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am a wall, and my breasts like towers: then was I in his eyes as one that found favour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; he let out the vineyard unto keepers; every one for the fruit thereof was to bring a thousand pieces of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My vineyard, which is mine, is before me: thou, O Solomon, must have a thousand, and those that keep the fruit thereof two hundred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thou that dwellest in the gardens, the companions hearken to thy voice: cause me to hear it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make haste, my beloved, and be thou like to a roe or to a young hart upon the mountains of spices.
verses.speaker: Narrator
